BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 15, 1918.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

NAVY SWAMPS LACROSSE TEAM

RAGGED GAME TO VIRGINIANS

SERVICE FLAG PRESENTATION

Punctures Hopkins Defense for Twelve
Goals — Morley, Silberstein and
Meyer Play Well for
Black and Blue.

After Gaining Big Lead, Hopkins Loses
Out to R.ndolph-Macon —"Doc"
Love Pitches Well, But Gets
Ragged Support.

Beta Circle of Omicron Delta Kappa
Presents Service Flag to Students-124 Stars- One
Gold Star.

With the strongest team they
have ever put on the field, the Naval Academy lacrosse team defeated the Hopkins Varsity, 12 to 0,
at Annapolis last Saturday. This
was the worst beating a Hopkins
team has suffered in many years.
Navy was strong, fast, and, in
tip-top condition, and always had
the jump on the Varsity. The
Hopkins attack was weakened by
the- absence of Winslow and Beall
and by the injury to Stuart, which
kept him out of half of the game.
The defense helped out as much
as they could, but were unable to
get away from the midshipmen,
who were very fast and had
enough stamina to set the pace
through the entire game. The
Hopkins points, Morley and Meyer, put up a splendid game, breaking down the Navy attack time
and again; they started the ball
out to the midfield, but it seldom
got within scoring distance.
"Sam" Silberstein, "Joe" Bremen
and "Dodo' Frisch played good
scrappy games, body checking the
midshipmen and following the
ball closely throughout the game.
Two of the Navy men were carried off the field as result of the
hard playing; but it was not all
on one side by any means. Hopkins men also spent some time on
the ground.
The first score came within a
minute of the opening of the
game, when Voinot, Navy third
attack, ran around the entireHopkins defense and tossed the ball to
Wisenbaker, who netted an easy
goal, uncovered, from the crease.
Most of Navy's goals were shot in
that way; the men would run
around the Hopkins men, get inside and shoot clean. During the
first half seven goals in all were
shot; Warner, Gearing and Shaw
getting the others between them.
At the beginning of the second
half Hopkins tightened, but Shaw
and Wisenbaker finally managed
to get the ball and shoot. During
the last few minutes, Warner,
Navy's first attack, ran wild, scoring three goals in rapid succession. During the second half
Navy kept sending in fresh men,
and were continually able to keep
U p the fast pace, though the Hopkins team strengthened considerably, sending Stanley in at cover
and bringing Meyer out to third,
where he could come through
more easily. The attack was helped, too, in the second half, by

On Saturday, April 13, Hopkins
again suffered defeat at the hands
of Randolf-Macon College, to the
tune of 8 to 5 in a generally wellplayed game. With the exception
of the seventh inning, in which
everything went wrong, the team
showed up well, easily outclassing
their opponents.
In the first inning Birdsong led
off for Randolf-Macon with a pass,
stealing second on the next ball.
Weikel knocked a slow ball down
the first base line, arriving safely
at the initial sack. In attempting
to steal second he was thrown out
by Dick-Benson. Birdsong scored
when Bloomburg booted Riddick's
grounder. Scott knocked a Texas
leaguer over Bloomburg's head,
placing Riddick on third. When
Scott stole second Riddick attempted to score, but was caught,
Littman to Benson. Hardy was
tossed out by Littman, thus ending the inning.
Hopkins came back in the
fourth round, "Doc" Co,x starting
the fun with a single to centre.
Webb forced him at second on a
fielder's choice. He made second
on a passed ball. Bloomsburg
beat out a grounder down the
third-base line. Rogers and Moriarity followed with singles, scoring Webb. Purcell fanned and
Love failed to connect with the
ball.
Davis, the Virginian's pitcher,
led off in the fifth with a single to
centre. Birdsong was Safe on
Bloornburg's wild heave to first.
Weikel forced Davis at third, and
Riddick followed with a two-bagger to left, scoring Birdsong.
Scott flied to Rogers, who threw
in to Littman, and Litman tossed
the ball to Cox, completing a fast
double play, nabbing Weikel off
third.
Benson led off. for the Black
and Blue with a free ticket. Littman connected for a single to
right. Cox bunted down the firstbase line, advancing Benson and
Littman. Webb followed with a
long two-bagger to centre, bringing in both runners. Bloomburg
made first when Hardy booted his
grounder. Rogers punched. Moriarity got safe when his hot
grounder went through Birdsong's
legs, s.coring Webb and Bloomburg. Purcell was out, Davis to
Talbott.

sixth. on an error and two sacrifice hits. Hopkins failed to con-

The Beta Circle of the Omicron
Delta Kappa will formally present a service flag to the students
of the University on Monday afternoon at 4.15 o'clock. The presentation will be a military ceremony similar to the presentation
of colors. M. K. Rothschild, president of Beta, will present the flag,
which will be received by President E. B. Jarrett, of the Student
Council.
There will be one hundred and
twenty-four stars—one of which
is gold—in the flag.

WINNING THE WAR IN AMERICA
By CHARLES BENNETT FOSTER.

(From the Patriotic News Service,
National Committee of Patriotic Societies, Washington, D. C.)

Washington today is the center
of all our war work. It is here
that all the plans are made. It
is here that all the orders are issued and all reports are sent. in
all the work made necessary by
this greatest task our country has
ever undertaken, there is much
confusion and inefficiency caused
by so many people trying to fill
positions for which they have had
no training. Here we find men
who have given up positions paying salaries all the way up to
$50,000 a year and accepting positions to work for the Government in this war for anywhere
from $1 a year to $200 or $300 a
month. These men are working
from 12 to 20 hours a day—living on such food as they can get—
which is sometimes poor—sleeping in crowded quarters, sacrificing all home ties and family life,
to help win the war.
We find girls working diligently at all kinds of office work—
eating in restaurants—sleeping 8
and 10 in a room—sacrificing social life, deprived of home comforts—all doing their best to win
the war.
Every office building is overcrowded; the Government having
taken most of the desirable buildings for its own use. It is almost
impossible to secure a •room in a
hotel. Boarding houses are all
crowded, and nowhere except in
the very high priced places is a
room rented to less than two people. Traffic conditions are seriously overtaxed. It is a rare
thing to see a gentleman seated in
a trolley car. To leave the city
by train, in either sleeper archair
car, reservation must be secured
long in advance.
One cannot but be impressed by
the seriousness expressed in the
faces on the street. The determination, the earnestness, the enthusiasm is infectious; everyone
catches the spirit that dominates
the thought of every mind to win
the war. It is not possible to be
in the midst of all this rush and
hustle without the wish to be part
of it. It forces itself into the
mind and into the heart of every
man.
This is the spirit that has come
to those who have learned the
secret, those who are willing to
do of their own free will, the
thing that Germany has been
compelled and forced to do by an

Douglas H. Gordon '87 Dead.

Douglas Huntly Gordon, A. B.
'87, one of the most prominent financiers of Baltimore died on last
Monday, April 8. Mr. Gordon
was one of the best-known alumni
of the Johns Hopkins University,
in which he always took an active
interest. The following editorial,
eulogizing Mr. Gordon, appeared
in the Baltimore News:
"The death of Douglas Huntly
Gordon takes from this community a great-hearted man the number of whose friends was the number of his acquaintances.
"In the financial circles where
his business activities lay he was
marked for his keen judgment of
investment values and his broad
appreciation of that higher standard of values that cannot be expressed in dollars alone. He was
not a money-grubber. There were
not in his character the first elements that go to make the harsh,
rough-riding financier, nor yet the
financier who conceals his iron
hand with a glove of treacherous
velvet. Had he possessed these he
might have left a void, but
' it
would not be the void Douglas
Gordon has left.
"All the world loves the man
whose first instinct is gentle
kindliness. Only the man who
lives in the atmosphere of great interests and wealth, yet keeps his
heart warm and open, his smile
ever ready and sincere, his mind
prepared always to understand
and sympathize, can attain to the
position Douglas Huntly Gordon
occupied in this community."

Battalion Drill on Monday.

All efforts are being put forth
toward having the battalion thoroughly prepared for the Government inspection, which is to take
place this month. After the setting up rifle exercises last Monday. Lieut. "Bill" Skinner put the
corps through a stiff bayonetdrill.
Then all three companies were
marched to Homewood field for
a drill of the entire battalion,
which was executed with few
hitches, all of which were quickly
corrected by Major Guild.
To Build Target Range.

At the end of drill an appeal
was made for volunteers to build
an indoor rifle range. Many came
forward, especially the junior engineers, and it is expected that
the battalion may soon start indoor target practice.

THIRD COTILLON ON MAY 11TH

Publicity Man for S. A.I. A.A. Games.

The Cotillon Board held a special meeting last Tuesday and
decided to hold the last big dance
of the year, Saturday, May 11
instead of Saturday, May 4, as
was previously announced.
The Board was led to change
the date because two of the spring
teams, the lacrosse and track
teams, will be out of town on that
day, and would not be able to get
back in time for the dance.
Then, too, Saturday, May 11,
will be a gala day for Hopkins,
inasmuch as two big athletic
events are scheduled at Homewood on that day. The Black and
Blue lacrosse team will bring its
schedule to a close with one of
the most important games of the
season—the Lehigh game—while
the track team will be striving for
honors in the S. A. I. A. A. meet.
These two events are bound to attract many of the graduates back,
so the board thought that holding
the big dance that night would
be a fitting climax for such an
eventful day.
The board is already forming
plans to make this last dance one
of the best ever held at Homewood.

At a recent meeting of the S.
A. I. A. A. games committee, Vernon E. Stuart, '20, was appointed
publicity manager for the week.
The idea of the committee is to
carry on the publicity in much
fife same way as was done for the
Armory meet, to the end that the
S. A. I. A. A. champs at Homewood may be generally recognized
as the great spring track and field
event of the South. Stuart is an
associate editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

BALTIMORE, MD

APRIL 15, 1918

Prepare for Inspection!

A Defeat Without Disgrace.
On last Saturday the Hopkins lacrosse team suffered a defeat
which, under ordinary circumstances, would have brought the darkest
gloom into the Hopkins camp. As it is, we accept the defeat, unashamed, with equanimity, an(l, perhaps, not without a degree of
pride. We gladly yield to Navy all the credit for the decisive victory
she won; but we must admit that we failed to feel the sting of an overwhelming defeat.
Hopkins lacrosse teams are not accustomed to defeat; nor are we
accustomed to explaining away lost lacrosse games. Lacrosse is to
Hopkins what football is to Harvard and Yale. In other words, we
take it as a matter of course that Hopkins shall have a championship
(or at least a "runner-up") lacrosse team. Last Saturday the Hopkins
lacrosse team suffered the most overwhelming defeat in ,the history of
Hopkins lacrosse.
Hopkins lacrosse need never have suffered the terrific dssault that
was made on its pride last Saturday. It might have adopted an "informal" lacrosse team this year, after the fashion of certain estimable
and large colleges. There was reason enough; there was not a single
regular left; military training conflicted with practices; almost every
member of the squad had to learn the ,game for the first time; the
coaches were unable to give the necessary time to the team. But Captain Schmidt's inexperienced men went down to Annapolis and faced
what is always one of the strongest teams in the country—a team
that was not handicapped in the least by the war. We were licked,and
we were licked badly; but we are proud to say that we played the
game.

When that inevitable command "Prepare for Inspection !"resounds
over Gilman Campus or Hotnevv-ood Field, will the Hopkins Battalion
be prepared?

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 15, 1918.

6

FRESHMEN HOLD STORMY SESSION
Effervescent Enthusiasm of Youngest
Class Borders on Bolshevikism.
Soph Spring Teams Will Have
Their Hands Full.
The Class of 1921 held another
one of its spirited meetings at
noon on Monday, April 8. As
usual the attendance was most
representative. On account of the
sickness of President Carey, Vice-

President Marcuse occupied the
pulpit.
The first topic for the earnest
consideration of the multitude
was the election of leaders for
the spring teams. For the • track
team "Reds" Mullikin was chosen
captain after a brief but bloody
struggle. This Irishman has an
enviable record with the Varsity
track team', getting a third in the
cross-country run last fall and

winning the South Atlantic mile
in the Armory meet. Joe Brennan, the Wisconsin rail-splitter,
was then unanimously elected
captain of the lacrosse team.
Brennan has shown up well this
spring with the lacrosse squad,
making one of the midfield positions on the Varsity. These captains should have no difficulty in
getting a large number of candidates out. "Jack" Jones, captain
of the baseball team, then dis-

cussed the question of baseball
practice grounds.
Lachlan Cattanach, the committee on class pins, next delivered
an impassioned appeal for those
who had ordered their articles to
come across with their "pinmoney," threatening all varieties
of dire misfortune if they did not.
The chairman succeeded in calming him.
After a little more bum argument the meeting adjourned.

Lecture on Military Law.

The bugle call for inclement
weather was sounded at 4 P. M.
last Thursday. Major Guild decided to lecture, and his subject
was "Military Law," with three
types of court-martial as his math
theme. The general court-martial,
.sed of thirteen officers and
comp°
a judge advocate, has jurisdiction
over all soldiers and in time of
war can administer the death penalty; while the special and summary courts-martial have jurisdiction over enlisted men only and
can administer only petty punishments. At the close of the lecture
the members of the battalion were
required to write out from memory the general orders of a sentinel.

THE TURKISH CIGARETTE

The hopes which the Hopkins
racqueters held for good weather
after the spring vacation have
been completely blasted. But during the week away from classes
some good preliminary work was
put in. As soon as some real
spring days come along, Manager Craft says, the men will be
in fine shape. As far as our
chances for bringing some victories to Hopkins go, the outlook
is bright. Besides the manager,
there are Beverly Smith, Hoffmeister, Wyckoff, all of whom
stood high while they were at City
College; Burger, Weinberg, Keys,
Hammond and Donaldson.
While the schedule is not yet
completed, it is certain that it
will be a very good one. A trip is
assured, in the early part of May,
to New York; on this trip, we
shall have mitches with Rutgers,
Haverford, Swarthmore, Pennsylvania, and others. A more definite
announcement of schedule will
be made soon.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 15, 1918.

TO INVESTIGATE HONOR SYSTEM

HOPKINS SONGSTERS TUNING UP SPEED MERCHANTS DRILLING UP

Student Council Committee to Investigate
Infractions—News-Letter Applies for
Authority Constitution—Publicity
Canpaign now Planned.

Glee and Instrumental Clubs Prepare for
McCoy Hall Concert on April 19th—
Quartet Promises to Be Roaring
Success—Coulter is Manager.

Cinder Path Artists Are Prepared for
Swarthmore Meet - Captain Firor has
a Promising Squad for the
Big Spring Meets.

At a meeting of the Student
Council last Tuesday night, the
recent protests against the abuse
of the honor system were considered. It was agreed that violations that may have occurred
were due chiefly to general ignorance on the part of the student
body concerning the details of
the system. Plans to vigorously
uphold the honor system and to
explain it fully to the undergraduate body were discussed, and
President Jarrett appointed a
committee to make a report on
suitable provisions.
The recent flood of letters to
THE NEWS-LETTER demanding action on the part of the Student
Council and the abolition of the
policing method recently resorted
to by some of the faculty is a testimonial of some of the vital interest shown by the students;
hence the Student Council has
taken vigorous steps toward putting the honor systeni on a solid
foundation.
THE NEWS-LETTER question was
next taken up at the behest of the
editor-in-chief. ,No constitution
governing THE .NEWS - LETTER
Board has been handed down to
the present editors, and therefore
no statutory punishment can be
meted out to those who fail to
hand in copy or are consistently

It was sought to establish a
firm connection between THE
NEWS - LETTER land the Student
Council, since the latter is a tribunal for all student activities. The
solution reached was to draw up
a constitution for THE NEWS-LETTER Board. This action Was taken
last Wednesday, but awaits the
approval of the Student Council.
Many changes in the organization
and time duties of the board were
incorporated into the constitution.
The Student Council has plans
on foot whereby more publicity
is to be directed to the organizations of all student activities.
Each and every student is to
know about the workings of the
athletic association, the musical
clubs, THE NEws LETTER, and in
short, every activity.

College activities will again
make the -recesses of McCoy Hall
ring with the old-time levity on
Friday evening, April 19, at 8.30
P. M. the Glee and Mandolin
clubs will give their annual concert and dance.
The first part of the evening
will be devoted to the musical
clubs. Glee music will be given
by a quartet composed of men of
-ample vocal ability. Townsend,
that fellow with a husky basso
military voice, will on next Friday night become a warbling first
tenor of the most entrancing type.
Leber will give a real demonstration of his latent musical talents
by singing second tenor. Coulter
will draw in his chin and pour
forth his rich baritone notes into
the bowl of harmony. Hardman
will make the audience quake
when he gives vent to his voluminous deep base voice. This combination of songsters in itself is
worth the price of admission.

The track team will take part
in its first meet of the outdoor
season when it travels up to tackle
Swarthmore, on Saturday, April
20. With the exception of this
last rainy week the squad has
been able to get plenty of practice, and, with one or two exceptions, is in first-class shape. The
rain,however, has given the bunch
a good rest-up.
Captain Fluor has announced
that he will take the two men
- that show up best in each event
in the trials. Of the distance men,
Rivkin and Mullikin have been
training for the 1AVOI mile and
mile. Norwood, Lord, and G. Cattanach are also candidates for
the mile. Hazeltine, Fischer, and
L. G. Smith have developed well
in the half-mile. In the shorter
distances and dashes the runners
will be picked from Bev. Smith,
VanNess Driver, "Eggie" Sutton,
Ebeling,'
Call, Torsch, Heiner, and
Mossonm. Captain Firor, Driver
and Chisholm will take care Of
the high jump they will likewise
enter the broad jump, in which'
they have already made good
showings. Seagrave will have the
pole vault, and, with Firor, will
compete in the hurdles. The
weights- will be handled by Leadbetter, a veteran at this end of the
game. Andrae is also practicing
with the weights.
The next Saturday after the
Swarthmore meet the relay men
will take part in the Penn. relay
carnival. Hopkins was fortunate
enough to draw the pole in the
South Atlantic relay, in which
they are entered. After that they
will have two weeks to practice
for the South Atlantics. The Nav
Cual meet, on May 4, was cancelled; on that date the freshn.en and sophomores will stage
thelr annual melee.
There is still room for new men
on the team, it is hoped that the
squad will be increased by many
additions when the spring weather starts in.

Punctures Hopkins Defense for Twelve
Goals — Morley, Silberstein and
Meyer Play Well for

After Gaining Big Lead, Hopkins Loses
Out to R.ndolph-Macon —"Doc"
Love Pitches Well, But Gets
Ragged Support.

Beta Circle of Omicron Delta Kappa

With the strongest team they
have ever put on the field, the Naval Academy lacrosse team defeated the Hopkins Varsity, 12 to 0,
at Annapolis last Saturday. This
was the worst beating a Hopkins
team has suffered in many years.
Navy was strong, fast, and, in
tip-top condition, and always had
the jump on the Varsity. The
Hopkins attack was weakened by
the- absence of Winslow and Beall
and by the injury to Stuart, which
kept him out of half of the game.
The defense helped out as much
as they could, but were unable to
get away from the midshipmen,
who were very fast and had
enough stamina to set the pace
through the entire game. The
Hopkins points, Morley and Meyer, put up a splendid game, breaking down the Navy attack time
and again; they started the ball
out to the midfield, but it seldom
got within scoring distance.
"Sam" Silberstein, "Joe" Bremen
and "Dodo' Frisch played good
scrappy games, body checking the
midshipmen and following the
ball closely throughout the game.
Two of the Navy men were carried off the field as result of the
hard playing; but it was not all
on one side by any means. Hopkins men also spent some time on
the ground.
The first score came within a
minute of the opening of the
game, when Voinot, Navy third
attack, ran around the entireHopkins defense and tossed the ball to
Wisenbaker, who netted an easy
goal, uncovered, from the crease.
Most of Navy's goals were shot in
that way; the men would run
around the Hopkins men, get inside and shoot clean. During the
first half seven goals in all were
shot; Warner, Gearing and Shaw
getting the others between them.
At the beginning of the second
half Hopkins tightened, but Shaw
and Wisenbaker finally managed
to get the ball and shoot. During
the last few minutes, Warner,
Navy's first attack, ran wild, scoring three goals in rapid succession. During the second half
Navy kept sending in fresh men,
and were continually able to keep
U p the fast pace, though the Hopkins team strengthened considerably, sending Stanley in at cover
and bringing Meyer out to third,
where he could come through
more easily. The attack was helped, too, in the second half, by

The Beta Circle of the Omicron
Delta Kappa will formally present a service flag to the students
of the University on Monday afternoon at 4.15 o'clock. The presentation will be a military ceremony similar to the presentation
of colors. M. K. Rothschild, president of Beta, will present the flag,
which will be received by President E. B. Jarrett, of the Student
Council.
There will be one hundred and
twenty-four stars—one of which
is gold—in the flag.

WINNING THE WAR IN AMERICA
By CHARLES BENNETT FOSTER.

(From the Patriotic News Service,
National Committee of Patriotic Societies, Washington, D. C.)

Washington today is the center
of all our war work. It is here
that all the plans are made. It
is here that all the orders are issued and all reports are sent. in
all the work made necessary by
this greatest task our country has
ever undertaken, there is much
confusion and inefficiency caused
by so many people trying to fill
positions for which they have had
no training. Here we find men
who have given up positions paying salaries all the way up to
$50,000 a year and accepting positions to work for the Government in this war for anywhere
from $1 a year to $200 or $300 a
month. These men are working
from 12 to 20 hours a day—living on such food as they can get—
which is sometimes poor—sleeping in crowded quarters, sacrificing all home ties and family life,
to help win the war.
We find girls working diligently at all kinds of office work—
eating in restaurants—sleeping 8
and 10 in a room—sacrificing social life, deprived of home comforts—all doing their best to win
the war.
Every office building is overcrowded; the Government having
taken most of the desirable buildings for its own use. It is almost
impossible to secure a •room in a
hotel. Boarding houses are all
crowded, and nowhere except in
the very high priced places is a
room rented to less than two people. Traffic conditions are seriously overtaxed. It is a rare
thing to see a gentleman seated in
a trolley car. To leave the city
by train, in either sleeper archair
car, reservation must be secured
long in advance.
One cannot but be impressed by
the seriousness expressed in the
faces on the street. The determination, the earnestness, the enthusiasm is infectious; everyone
catches the spirit that dominates
the thought of every mind to win
the war. It is not possible to be
in the midst of all this rush and
hustle without the wish to be part
of it. It forces itself into the
mind and into the heart of every
man.
This is the spirit that has come
to those who have learned the
secret, those who are willing to
do of their own free will, the
thing that Germany has been
compelled and forced to do by an

Douglas H. Gordon '87 Dead.

Douglas Huntly Gordon, A. B.
'87, one of the most prominent financiers of Baltimore died on last
Monday, April 8. Mr. Gordon
was one of the best-known alumni
of the Johns Hopkins University,
in which he always took an active
interest. The following editorial,
eulogizing Mr. Gordon, appeared
in the Baltimore News:
"The death of Douglas Huntly
Gordon takes from this community a great-hearted man the number of whose friends was the number of his acquaintances.
"In the financial circles where
his business activities lay he was
marked for his keen judgment of
investment values and his broad
appreciation of that higher standard of values that cannot be expressed in dollars alone. He was
not a money-grubber. There were
not in his character the first elements that go to make the harsh,
rough-riding financier, nor yet the
financier who conceals his iron
hand with a glove of treacherous
velvet. Had he possessed these he
might have left a void, but
' it
would not be the void Douglas
Gordon has left.
"All the world loves the man
whose first instinct is gentle
kindliness. Only the man who
lives in the atmosphere of great interests and wealth, yet keeps his
heart warm and open, his smile
ever ready and sincere, his mind
prepared always to understand
and sympathize, can attain to the
position Douglas Huntly Gordon
occupied in this community."

Battalion Drill on Monday.

All efforts are being put forth
toward having the battalion thoroughly prepared for the Government inspection, which is to take
place this month. After the setting up rifle exercises last Monday. Lieut. "Bill" Skinner put the
corps through a stiff bayonetdrill.
Then all three companies were
marched to Homewood field for
a drill of the entire battalion,
which was executed with few
hitches, all of which were quickly
corrected by Major Guild.
To Build Target Range.

was made for volunteers to build
an indoor rifle range. Many came
forward, especially the junior engineers, and it is expected that
the battalion may soon start indoor target practice.

THIRD COTILLON ON MAY 11TH

Publicity Man for S. A.I. A.A. Games.

The Cotillon Board held a special meeting last Tuesday and
decided to hold the last big dance
of the year, Saturday, May 11
instead of Saturday, May 4, as
was previously announced.
The Board was led to change
the date because two of the spring
teams, the lacrosse and track
teams, will be out of town on that
day, and would not be able to get
back in time for the dance.
Then, too, Saturday, May 11,
will be a gala day for Hopkins,
inasmuch as two big athletic
events are scheduled at Homewood on that day. The Black and
Blue lacrosse team will bring its
schedule to a close with one of
the most important games of the
season—the Lehigh game—while
the track team will be striving for
honors in the S. A. I. A. A. meet.
These two events are bound to attract many of the graduates back,
so the board thought that holding
the big dance that night would
be a fitting climax for such an
eventful day.
The board is already forming
plans to make this last dance one
of the best ever held at Homewood.

At a recent meeting of the S.
A. I. A. A. games committee, Vernon E. Stuart, '20, was appointed
publicity manager for the week.
The idea of the committee is to
carry on the publicity in much
fife same way as was done for the
Armory meet, to the end that the
S. A. I. A. A. champs at Homewood may be generally recognized
as the great spring track and field
event of the South. Stuart is an
associate editor of THE NEWS-LETTER.

BALTIMORE, MD

APRIL 15, 1918

Prepare for Inspection!

A Defeat Without Disgrace.
On last Saturday the Hopkins lacrosse team suffered a defeat
which, under ordinary circumstances, would have brought the darkest
gloom into the Hopkins camp. As it is, we accept the defeat, unashamed, with equanimity, an(l, perhaps, not without a degree of
pride. We gladly yield to Navy all the credit for the decisive victory
she won; but we must admit that we failed to feel the sting of an overwhelming defeat.
Hopkins lacrosse teams are not accustomed to defeat; nor are we
accustomed to explaining away lost lacrosse games. Lacrosse is to
Hopkins what football is to Harvard and Yale. In other words, we
take it as a matter of course that Hopkins shall have a championship
(or at least a "runner-up") lacrosse team. Last Saturday the Hopkins
lacrosse team suffered the most overwhelming defeat in ,the history of
Hopkins lacrosse.
Hopkins lacrosse need never have suffered the terrific dssault that
was made on its pride last Saturday. It might have adopted an "informal" lacrosse team this year, after the fashion of certain estimable
and large colleges. There was reason enough; there was not a single
regular left; military training conflicted with practices; almost every
member of the squad had to learn the ,game for the first time; the
coaches were unable to give the necessary time to the team. But Captain Schmidt's inexperienced men went down to Annapolis and faced
what is always one of the strongest teams in the country—a team
that was not handicapped in the least by the war. We were licked,and
we were licked badly; but we are proud to say that we played the
game.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, APRIL 15, 1918.

6

FRESHMEN HOLD STORMY SESSION
Effervescent Enthusiasm of Youngest
Class Borders on Bolshevikism.
Soph Spring Teams Will Have
Their Hands Full.
The Class of 1921 held another
one of its spirited meetings at
noon on Monday, April 8. As
usual the attendance was most
representative. On account of the
sickness of President Carey, Vice-

President Marcuse occupied the
pulpit.
The first topic for the earnest
consideration of the multitude
was the election of leaders for
the spring teams. For the • track
team "Reds" Mullikin was chosen
captain after a brief but bloody
struggle. This Irishman has an
enviable record with the Varsity
track team', getting a third in the
cross-country run last fall and

winning the South Atlantic mile
in the Armory meet. Joe Brennan, the Wisconsin rail-splitter,
was then unanimously elected
captain of the lacrosse team.
Brennan has shown up well this
spring with the lacrosse squad,
making one of the midfield positions on the Varsity. These captains should have no difficulty in
getting a large number of candidates out. "Jack" Jones, captain
of the baseball team, then dis-

cussed the question of baseball
practice grounds.
Lachlan Cattanach, the committee on class pins, next delivered
an impassioned appeal for those
who had ordered their articles to
come across with their "pinmoney," threatening all varieties
of dire misfortune if they did not.
The chairman succeeded in calming him.
After a little more bum argument the meeting adjourned.

Lecture on Military Law.

The bugle call for inclement
weather was sounded at 4 P. M.
last Thursday. Major Guild decided to lecture, and his subject
was "Military Law," with three
types of court-martial as his math
theme. The general court-martial,
.sed of thirteen officers and
comp°
a judge advocate, has jurisdiction
over all soldiers and in time of
war can administer the death penalty; while the special and summary courts-martial have jurisdiction over enlisted men only and
can administer only petty punishments. At the close of the lecture
the members of the battalion were
required to write out from memory the general orders of a sentinel.

THE TURKISH CIGARETTE

The hopes which the Hopkins
racqueters held for good weather
after the spring vacation have
been completely blasted. But during the week away from classes
some good preliminary work was
put in. As soon as some real
spring days come along, Manager Craft says, the men will be
in fine shape. As far as our
chances for bringing some victories to Hopkins go, the outlook
is bright. Besides the manager,
there are Beverly Smith, Hoffmeister, Wyckoff, all of whom
stood high while they were at City
College; Burger, Weinberg, Keys,
Hammond and Donaldson.
While the schedule is not yet
completed, it is certain that it
will be a very good one. A trip is
assured, in the early part of May,
to New York; on this trip, we
shall have mitches with Rutgers,
Haverford, Swarthmore, Pennsylvania, and others. A more definite
announcement of schedule will
be made soon.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, APRIL 15, 1918.

TO INVESTIGATE HONOR SYSTEM

HOPKINS SONGSTERS TUNING UP SPEED MERCHANTS DRILLING UP

Student Council Committee to Investigate
Infractions—News-Letter Applies for
Authority Constitution—Publicity
Canpaign now Planned.

Glee and Instrumental Clubs Prepare for
McCoy Hall Concert on April 19th—
Quartet Promises to Be Roaring
Success—Coulter is Manager.

Cinder Path Artists Are Prepared for
Swarthmore Meet - Captain Firor has
a Promising Squad for the
Big Spring Meets.

At a meeting of the Student
Council last Tuesday night, the
recent protests against the abuse
of the honor system were considered. It was agreed that violations that may have occurred
were due chiefly to general ignorance on the part of the student
body concerning the details of
the system. Plans to vigorously
uphold the honor system and to
explain it fully to the undergraduate body were discussed, and
President Jarrett appointed a
committee to make a report on
suitable provisions.
The recent flood of letters to
THE NEWS-LETTER demanding action on the part of the Student
Council and the abolition of the
policing method recently resorted
to by some of the faculty is a testimonial of some of the vital interest shown by the students;
hence the Student Council has
taken vigorous steps toward putting the honor systeni on a solid
foundation.
THE NEWS-LETTER question was
next taken up at the behest of the
editor-in-chief. ,No constitution
governing THE .NEWS - LETTER
Board has been handed down to
the present editors, and therefore
no statutory punishment can be
meted out to those who fail to
hand in copy or are consistently
absent from me6tings.
It was sought to establish a
firm connection between THE
NEWS - LETTER land the Student
Council, since the latter is a tribunal for all student activities. The
solution reached was to draw up
a constitution for THE NEWS-LETTER Board. This action Was taken
last Wednesday, but awaits the
approval of the Student Council.
Many changes in the organization
and time duties of the board were
incorporated into the constitution.
The Student Council has plans
on foot whereby more publicity
is to be directed to the organizations of all student activities.
Each and every student is to
know about the workings of the
athletic association, the musical
clubs, THE NEws LETTER, and in
short, every activity.

College activities will again
make the -recesses of McCoy Hall
ring with the old-time levity on
Friday evening, April 19, at 8.30
P. M. the Glee and Mandolin
clubs will give their annual concert and dance.
The first part of the evening
will be devoted to the musical
clubs. Glee music will be given
by a quartet composed of men of
-ample vocal ability. Townsend,
that fellow with a husky basso
military voice, will on next Friday night become a warbling first
tenor of the most entrancing type.
Leber will give a real demonstration of his latent musical talents
by singing second tenor. Coulter
will draw in his chin and pour
forth his rich baritone notes into
the bowl of harmony. Hardman
will make the audience quake
when he gives vent to his voluminous deep base voice. This combination of songsters in itself is
worth the price of admission.

The track team will take part
in its first meet of the outdoor
season when it travels up to tackle
Swarthmore, on Saturday, April
20. With the exception of this
last rainy week the squad has
been able to get plenty of practice, and, with one or two exceptions, is in first-class shape. The
rain,however, has given the bunch
a good rest-up.
Captain Fluor has announced
that he will take the two men
- that show up best in each event
in the trials. Of the distance men,
Rivkin and Mullikin have been
training for the 1AVOI mile and
mile. Norwood, Lord, and G. Cattanach are also candidates for
the mile. Hazeltine, Fischer, and
L. G. Smith have developed well
in the half-mile. In the shorter
distances and dashes the runners
will be picked from Bev. Smith,
VanNess Driver, "Eggie" Sutton,
Ebeling,'
Call, Torsch, Heiner, and
Mossonm. Captain Firor, Driver
and Chisholm will take care Of
the high jump they will likewise
enter the broad jump, in which'
they have already made good
showings. Seagrave will have the
pole vault, and, with Firor, will
compete in the hurdles. The
weights- will be handled by Leadbetter, a veteran at this end of the
game. Andrae is also practicing
with the weights.
The next Saturday after the
Swarthmore meet the relay men
will take part in the Penn. relay
carnival. Hopkins was fortunate
enough to draw the pole in the
South Atlantic relay, in which
they are entered. After that they
will have two weeks to practice
for the South Atlantics. The Nav
Cual meet, on May 4, was cancelled; on that date the freshn.en and sophomores will stage
thelr annual melee.
There is still room for new men
on the team, it is hoped that the
squad will be increased by many
additions when the spring weather starts in.

The music of the Mandolin
Club will also be an important
feature of the entertainment.
Composed of about 25 skilled pickers, the club will render various
selections, under the impulse of
which feet will refuse to remain
quiet. Judging from recent rehearsals, frequent and full of ginger, nothing will be lacking in
this part of the program.
More interesting to many, however, will be the dance, which will
follow the musical program. The
dance, as has been arranged by
shortening the musical entertainment, will fill most of the evening.
A good orchestra will furnish the
music, by which those who desire
may exhibit their skill in the
terpsichorean art.

Doug. Coulter, who is managing
the whole affair, regrets that the
student body is not manifesting
as much interest in the concert as
it should. Tickets have been distributed through the postoffice,
but the response to this strong invitation to attend the concert is
